meanings.definition: Empirics: knowledge gained through observation or experience.
meanings.sent1: She trusted the empirics of her own eyes to understand the world around her.
meanings.sent2: The scientist's empirics were crucial in forming his theories about nature.
meanings.sent3: The detective's empirics led her to solve the mysterious case in record time.
meanings.sent4: His empirics were like a flashlight in the dark, illuminating the path to truth.
meanings.sent5: The teacher used hands-on empirics to help students grasp complex concepts easily.

meanings.definition: Empirics: a person who relies on practical experience rather than theory.
meanings.sent1: As an empirics, he valued real-world knowledge over abstract ideas.
meanings.sent2: The old sailor was a true empirics, having learned everything about the sea through practice.
meanings.sent3: The chef, a seasoned empirics, could whip up a delicious meal without following any recipes.
meanings.sent4: She was an empirics in the art of negotiation, always relying on her instincts to strike a deal.
meanings.sent5: The carpenter, a skilled empirics, could build anything without needing a blueprint.

meanings.definition: Empirics: relating to or based on empiricism.
meanings.sent1: The empirics approach to learning emphasized hands-on experience over theory.
meanings.sent2: Her empirics research focused on practical applications rather than abstract concepts.
meanings.sent3: The empirics perspective on life made him appreciate the value of direct observation.
meanings.sent4: In the world of business, an empirics mindset can lead to innovative solutions.
